en.value: We're going on holiday.
Booking and planning a holiday - First conditional, Time expressions
Pack the suncream!
Are you going on holiday?
Yes, I've taken some time off and booked a trip.
Where are you going?
A short getaway to Sweden, my flight is tomorrow morning.
You should start packing!
Everyone loves going on holiday! In this unit we’ll learn some useful vocabulary we can use when planning a holiday.
Here's a tip!
to go [k]on holiday[/k]
to holiday
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
to go on holiday
If the weather is nice we'll go on holiday this summer.
Memorise the word(s).
to book
I just booked a holiday to Antigua.
Match the beginning and the end of each sentence.
I am going
I have booked
on a holiday next week.
a two-week holiday.
Have you [k]b[/k][k]o[/k]o[k]k[/k][k]e[/k][k]d[/k] your holidays yet?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.

We have already learned the phrase "to go on holiday". We can also use "to go on..." with words like "a cruise", "a trip", "an adventure" or "a tour" to talk more about holidays. Let's see some examples.
We are going on a cruise around the Mediterranean.
We went on a trip to Berlin last week.
My friend and I are going on an adventure!
I went on a tour of the Greek islands.
flight
I changed my flight and I'm leaving tomorrow.
to take
Where can we take the bus to the airport?
To talk about how we get to a place we can say: to take a / the... or to travel by... Let's see some useful examples.
I like taking the train. / I like travelling by train.
What are Tom's holiday plans?
He will be travelling alone to different cities in the south of Spain.
He will be travelling to Australia with his friend Joe.
He will be travelling with Joe to the south of Spain by bus.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
We are taking
We are travelling
a flight.
by plane.
to get away
It will be good to get away for a couple of weeks.

We've just learned a useful verb combination; "to get away" this is the action to go somewhere for holiday, usually because you need to rest. As other verbs in English, it has an equivalent noun to talk about the place where we go to relax or just to refer to a short holiday: a getaway. Pay attention to the spelling when we talk about the action of going on a short break we write two words!
Noun (a short trip): Just a short getaway to my parents' house near the coast.
Verb ( to go on holiday): I am so stressed I need to get away a couple of days.
Match the beginning with the end of the sentence.
I am getting
I am planning
away in January for a ski weekend in the Alps.
a weekend getaway to go skiing in the Alps.
package
If we book a package holiday it will be cheaper.
pack
Have you packed the sun cream?
The [k]package[/k] includes flights from London.
pack
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
to get somewhere
How long does it take to get to Singapore?
to take some time off
You need to take some time off and relax!
Which sentence contains a verb meaning “to travel”?
We get to Paris by train.
We go to Paris in a week.
We get away to Paris for a week.
We all need to [k]take[/k] some time [k]off[/k] now and then.
go
on
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
[k]Let's[/k] [k]go[/k] [k]on[/k] [k]a[/k] [k]trip[/k][k]![/k]
Select the words in the correct order.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
3 days to go!
Ugh, I get it! You’re [k]going on holiday[/k]. No need to remind me every two seconds…
I’m so excited! I’ve booked my [k]flights[/k]. I’m [k]going on an adventure[/k]! Do you want to know where?
Oh, go on, then… Where are you going? When do you go?
I’m [k]flying to[/k] Mexico on the 26th of March. I’m visiting Mexico City and travelling to Acapulco.
That's cool. Have you [k]booked a tour[/k]?
Yeah, the [k]package[/k] includes transport and hotels.
I'm [k]taking some time off[/k] next week, a short [k]getaway[/k] to Sweden. I can't wait to swim in lakes and eat lots of herring.
Herring!? Ugh!
Naomi
Nathan
Naomi is going on a tour of Mexico and…
Nathan is going on a cruise to a lake in Sweden.
Nathan has booked a travel package to Sweden.
Nathan is going on a short trip to Sweden.
I booked my [k]flights|flight[/k] to Mexico at the beginning of the year.
A journey on a plane.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
I've packed
I've booked
the swimming suit!
a package holiday.
Select the two words that mean the same in this context as “travelling by".
They will [h]take[/h] [h]a[/h] plane from Gatwick tomorrow evening.
I am taking some time off next week, a short [k]getaway[/k] to Sweden.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Select the correct definition.
to get away
a getaway
to go on holiday
a holiday, or a place where you go on holiday
I am going to [k]book[/k] a trip to the South of Spain.
Similar in meaning to "to reserve".
I am going to start [k]packing[/k]!
Why don't you take some time [k]off[/k]?
Complete the sentence to suggest that the person take a break.
We all need a break now and then. Where do you want to go on holiday? What can you do there? How long does it take to get there?
I really want to go to ... / There are lots of ... / It takes ... hours by ...
Grammar: First conditional

Conditional sentences are very useful and common in many languages. A conditional sentence has two parts: a condition using "if", and a result that will occur if the condition is met. Let's have a look at an example: "If the weather is nice, we'll go to the beach."
The condition clause or if-clause in bold expresses a condition: "If the weather is nice..."
The result clause or main clause in bold tells us the result if the condition is met: "we'll go to the beach"
This sentence has two parts: one of the parts establishes a condition for the other to be true.
If the weather is nice, we will go to the beach.
True or false?
Select the three words that form a condition (if-clause):
I will go with you [h]if[/h] [h]I'm[/h] [h]free[/h].
If I take some time off, [h]I'll[/h] [h]go[/h] [h]to[/h] [h]Spain[/h].
Select the clause that tell us the result if the condition is met.

There are a few different structures of conditional sentences. For now let's focus on one that we call the "first conditional". We use the first conditional type when we know that it's possible and likely that the condition will be fulfilled. In the first conditional, the if-clause is in the present simple, and the main clause is in the future simple .
If-clause / condition (present simple)
Main clause / result (future simple "will")
If I'm free,
I'll go with you to the party.
If you don't hurry up,
we'll miss the train.
If I cancel tonight,
will the hotel charge me?
If I'm busy,
I won't go to the concert.
Using the first conditional
If I'm free,
If I'm busy,
I'll go to the party.
I won't go to the party.
Select the main clause (result) for this if-clause (condition): If the flights are too expensive, ...
we took the train.
we would take the train.
we will take the train.
Conditional sentence order
We can switch the order of the if-clause (condition) and the main clause (result). Notice that we only use a comma when the if clause goes first. Have a look at the sentence below.
If it rains, we won't do a barbeque.
We won't do a barbeque if it rains.
[k]If[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]cook[/k][k],[/k] [k]I'll[/k] [k]bring[/k] [k]dessert.[/k]
Arrange the first conditional sentence, putting the if-clause first.
If I [k]book[/k] in advance, the flights [k]will be[/k] cheaper.
are
will book
Listen to the dialogue on the next screen and try to spot all the first conditional sentences.
Let's see some first conditional sentences in action!
Hi Ada, the guys and I are planning to go on a short getaway this bank holiday. If the weather is nice, [k]we'll go[/k] to the beach. Do you have any plans?
That sounds great! I'll definitely come [k]if[/k] I'm free.
Great! If you let me know soon, [k]I'll book[/k].
[k]If you cancel[/k], will we have to pay anything?
We won't have to pay anything [k]if we cancel[/k] before Tuesday.
Brilliant! Is Peter coming too?
Peter? Um, we don't get along well. If he asks, don't tell him about our plans.
John
Ada
Complete the sentence: If you cancel, ...
will we have to pay anything?
did we have to pay anything?
have you paid anything?
[k]If[/k] [k]I'm[/k] [k]free[/k][k],[/k][k]I´ll[/k] [k]go[/k].
Put the sentence into the right order, with the if-clause first.
I'm busy, I [k]won't go|will not go[/k] to the party.
future simple of "to go" - negative
You will learn English if you [k]practise|practice[/k] a little every day.
Complete the sentence with the correct tense and the verb "to practise".
When do we use the first conditional structure?
when it is possible or likely that something will happen
when it is not likely that something will happen
when it is impossible that something will happen
Select the correct option to finish the sentence: In a first conditional sentence...
the if-clause is in the present simple and the result in the future simple.
the if-clause is in the future simple and the result in the present simple.
the if-clause is in the present perfect and the result in the future simple.
Who else will come with us if I [k]book[/k] a getaway?
Correct tense of "to book".
If he asks, don't tell him about our plans.
If you don't water the plants, they die.

In this unit we have focused on the first type of conditional, which expresses that a condition is likely to happen. In the dialogue we saw another type of conditional structure, which we call the "zero conditional". We form this with the simple present tense in both clauses, and it usually expresses a general fact or gives an instruction:
If clause (simple present)
Main clause (simple future)
If I'm free,
I'll go with you to the party.
If you don't hurry up,
we´ll miss the train.
If I cancel tonight,
will the hotel charge me?
If it [k]rains[/k], we will stay at home.
Correct tense of "to rain".
Grammar: Time expressions

Julia went on holiday a couple of weeks ago. She wrote an email to her friend to tell him how everything went. Let's have a look at her email. Notice how she uses different expressions to talk about time.

How's everything? I haven't heard from you since last month. I'm back from my holiday. I went to Sicily with my sister a couple of weeks ago, and we loved it! We arrived on Saturday and stayed at my friend's house for three days. Then, we rented an apartment next to the beach and stayed there until Sunday. It's so hot there during summer! I think I'd prefer spring or autumn - it's cooler.
ago
I went on holiday a couple of weeks ago.
We use "ago" to say when a past event happened. It always goes after an expression of time, and the verb in the sentence is in the past simple because it refers to a finished period of time.
We went on holiday two weeks ago.
I finished university five years ago.
They saw him a while ago.
I saw Claire three days ago.
This sentence describes when a past event happened.
[k]I[/k] [k]went[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]London[/k] [k]two[/k] [k]months[/k] [k]ago.[/k]
during
We went for a walk during the day.
for
He worked at the shop for three years.
We use "for", followed by a period of time, to say for how long something goes on. We use "during" to say when something happens.
I went on holiday for a week.
We visited many museums during the holidays.
It rained [k]for[/k] three hours.
ago
I went to the beach every day [k]during[/k] the holidays.
at
since
It hasn't rained since last week.

We use "since" to refer to the starting point of actions or situations. We normally use it with the present perfect, but depending on where we are in the world, we might hear some using it with the past simple.
I've lived here since 1995.
I've been awake since 5.30am.
We haven't spoken [k]since[/k] last month.
for
until
We were on holiday until the end of September.

We use "until" to say when something continues up to a specific time. We can also use "till" instead of "until". They both have the same meaning, but "till" is more informal and only really used in spoken language.
I'm in London till Sunday.
The shops are open until 8pm on Thursdays.
Complete the sentence: I was in the office ... late.
until
since
during
I travelled [k]for[/k] a month.
ago
Complete the sentence: I have been in the office ... 8am.
since
for
ago
Here’s a quick recap of all the words and expressions we’ve learned. Have one more look before we practise some more.
since last month
a couple of weeks ago
for three days
until Sunday
You're doing great! Let's have a look at some other useful time expressions we frequently use in English.
We arrived at the airport two hours before the flight.
She went to the gym after breakfast.
Someone came while you were out.
before
We arrived at the airport two hours before the flight.
after
She went to the gym after breakfast.

We use "before" to talk about an action that happened earlier than another one, and "after" to describe an action that happened at a later time. We can be more vague and not specify exactly when something is happening by saying "earlier" and "later" at the end of the sentence. Let's have a look at these examples:
I'll do the shopping after work.
I'll do the shopping later.
I spoke to him before the meeting.
I spoke to him earlier.
[k]I[/k] [k]was[/k] [k]nervous[/k] [k]before[/k] [k]the[/k] [k]exam.[/k]
I went to the gym [k]after[/k] work.
before
Listen to the audio and complete the sentence with the correct word.
Theresa had breakfast [k]before[/k] going to the hairdresser.
after
while
Someone came while you were out.
We can also use "a while" to refer to a period of time (usually a fairly short time). Let's have a look at the following expressions.
in a while: I'll call you in a while.
for a while: I haven't seen you for a while.
a while ago: We visited him a while ago.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
I'll go to the shops
I saw him
in a while.
a while ago.
We went away [k]for[/k] three weeks
ago
I watched a film [k]after[/k] dinner.
later
My children finished school a few days [k]ago[/k].
for
I'll make dinner [k]w[/k][k]h[/k][k]i[/k][k]l[/k][k]e[/k] you set the table.
Complete the sentence with the correct preposition.
I went away [k]for[/k] a couple of weeks.
I went for a swim every day [k]during[/k] the summer.
I stayed in the hotel [k]until[/k] yesterday.
while
I have been here [k]since[/k] 8am.
I'll see you [k]in[/k] a [k]while[/k].
ago
during
I bought a new dress a couple of days [k]ago[/k].
I waited [k]till[/k] 7pm, but he didn't come.
I went to the shops [k]e[/k][k]a[/k][k]r[/k][k]l[/k][k]i[/k][k]e[/k][k]r[/k].
I went to my parents house a [k]while[/k] [k]ago[/k].
for
during
Complete the sentence to describe an action that happened at a later time.
I'll go to the supermarket [k]after[/k] work.
